The information here is primarily for patients at reduced risk of CVD, with symptoms of dyslipidemia or the presence of a risk factor, such as obesity or smoking, that warrants consideration.
The person is likely to be a woman.
The person needs to have a family history of CVD or a history of smoking that is above 30% for their ethnic groups/regions, which in the particular case they were from.
Anything which the people or institutions are considering should be carefully scrutinised - e.g., a history of diabetes, obesity, obesity without signs of hypoglycemia or cardiovascular disease, diabetes despite having a high cholesterol profile, smoking prior to diagnosis, diabetes with a history of insulin resistance, or genetic testing for any of the above.
Based on the information in the evidence, the person should be assessed for CVD. If the person has not responded to that assessment, the next step would be to speak with the patient first. As per this guideline, the patient has to be offered a range of treatment options based on the above, such as, regular physiotherapy if diabetes/hypertension is ruled out. The person will also need a referral from their surgeon to have surgery. Once an individual has been treated on the basis of the available evidence about CVD risk factors or interventions, they should be referred back to the GP, preferably at least one hour later in the evening.
After an individual’s GP has referred someone back to the GP, referral is usually initiated by a multidisciplinary team.
The team may include nurses, dietitian, social worker, psychologist or consultant Psychiatrist based on the evidence available for this individual’s CVD. The patient should be admitted into a hospital only as long as they wish to be admitted to the hospital or the person needs a surgical intervention to be brought back to hospital as the patient has an underlying risk of CVD, for instance if they have heart disease. Also, in the case of their diabetes or severe obesity, the GP may have to go to be seen, if that person is admitted to hospital or surgery. In the later, there may be restrictions since a surgical intervention could be recommended.
A person who needs a coronary angiogram or stress test with cardiac catheterisation or an interventional radiologist may benefit from consultation with a consultant psychiatrist.
A person may be given advice as to what he or she needs to do if they want to stop smoking, as well as advice after they stop smoking on how to go about self-care; if they need medication for their condition, they should be aware of the latest available products for this reason.
The person should have a referral if they are at high risk of CVD, so as to be sure that their treatment plan is based on the best available evidence.
The advice may have to be given by a specialist consultant psychiatrist or a GP. In the case where there is no previous history of CVD or diabetes, the referral to them should be done beforehand.
When there is no previous history of CVD, the consultant may ask the person for background information about the person’s CVD history and the need for an assessment of this. It can also determine whether the person has been taking any medication for CVD and whether they are obese or not.
A person may need a referral from a specialist psychiatrist or a GP, because they do not know if they have CVD or already do and that is often a reason for a referral.
If one of the people on the consult list has had a previous episode of cardiovascular disease, they may become stressed and this can make a referral necessary. It must be made to the doctor or primary care doctor. When it is time for a request for referral, it should only be done in a specialist consultant psychiatrist rather than in the GP.
When asked for background information on the person’s CVD history as well as their smoking status, the person should be asked about their past BMI, diabetes history, cholesterol and cardiovascular fitness.
In any case, the person should have no history of smoking.
When it is time for a referral to the consultant psychiatrist, it should be done by the psychiatrist.
Patients must not receive this care unless they have had a referral (under the patient’s permission if the person does not wish to have it) and have been advised about the needs that their CVD and the interventions that can be made. When a person who needs a coronary angiogram has their angiogram done they should be kept informed because this treatment is crucial.

Cochlear Implants in adults with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss should be identified and evaluated.
This study focuses on the effectiveness of a cochlear implant device (CEI) in a population of adults with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and other age-related hearing loss and age-matched controls.
The CECI (Hearing Centers Consortium for Adult Cochlear Implantation) is a clinical trial involving 687 adults with a history of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) over 6 to 20 years.
Participants include women, men, and adolescents between 16 to 23 years of age who are seeking help with ASHP1, ASHP2, or ASHP5 hearing loss.
Participants are assessed using a comprehensive physical examination including a hearing test. All participants participate in a clinical trial, including a risk assessment, a baseline assessment, a randomized trial, and a posttreatment post-treatment follow-up.
Overall, researchers found significant improvements in hearing acuity two years after participants completed their clinical trial. Among these participants, there was a 20.4 (95% confidence interval [CI], 17.5-23.6) increase in auditory threshold between baseline and pre-trial, and a 20.4 (95% CI, 16.3-26.2) increase in temporal resolution over baseline. Participants with SNHL demonstrated an average of 7.9 (95% CI, 6.1-9.5) new hearing loss in the age group 16 to 23 years on at least one test. Additionally, participant groups receiving a CECI were significantly less likely to have a history of another SNHL, and less likely to use FM or other nonhearing aids. It is hoped that better understanding of the mechanisms involved in hearing loss and that a better understanding of the benefit or burdens of hearing assistive devices in people with hearing loss will support this clinical trial.

To use this tool with our Patient Data Management Plan to evaluate the patient's heart condition, I recommend setting the following criteria:

* BMI (weight in kilograms divided by square meters of height in meters)
* Total Cholesterol (for women between 25 and 30)
* HDL Cholesterol (for men between 25 and 35)
* Blood Pressure (measured via an automated blood pressure machine)
* Diabetes (diagnosed either Type I or Type II)
* Family History of CVD (If your husband or sister is a patient with CVD)
* Use of statin products
**Please note that you must log out and then re-enter your password before accessing the tool.** This tool is designed to be used on a computer with a Windows 10 machine. It is designed to give recommendations about your risk for CVD based on these characteristics alone.

You can see how our patient lives without CVD or what lifestyle factors are preventing their diagnosis. However, this tool cannot replace the need for a detailed medical history and full evaluation by a cardiologist if you require a heart condition diagnosis. You need to visit a cardiologist as your primary care provider. Some patients need to be followed for years before diagnosing or determining a prognosis. In such cases, patient lifestyle factors will not change. Once you are screened, you will be referred to a cardiologist for a detailed physical examination and ECG. You will be referred to a cardiologist, who will give you a recommendation for lifestyle changes and a prescription for medication. These changes will be prescribed based on your risk factor and medical condition, and most prescription drugs must be monitored for a long term with repeated dosing. For some people, these lifestyle changes will be sufficient. For others, lifestyle changes have to be made more drastic.

If you are feeling frustrated and desperate, we encourage you to ask for help from your healthcare team, preferably with cardiovascular risk factors. They often know what your risk factors for CVD are and will be able to recommend a lifestyle change protocol or a prescription for a medication (with some restrictions based on patient characteristics).

This information is for educational purposes only. It's not intended to be and does not replace a proper medical consultation by a medical expert.

**Disclaimer:** The Healthcare facility that provided care for this patient is NOT REPRESENTATIVE of NICE. We provide the following guidelines for all patients. If you experience any health issues or concerns, please consult your healthcare professional.

##### Notes:
1. For older adults: Take medications to control blood pressure for at least one year prior to initiating statin therapy. If these lifestyle factors do not lower blood pressure, ask your doctor how to manage other blood pressure-related conditions.
2. Beware of other lifestyle factors, such as alcohol use, physical inactivity, smoking, and psychiatric illnesses such as schizophrenia, anxiety disorders, depression, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
3. Get your blood work done to rule out high cholesterol and check for polycystic ovary syndrome.
4. If heart failure is suspected, check your heart rhythm. A pulse oximeter works very well for monitoring heart rates, but you might want to measure your blood oxygen level.
5. If you need oxygen, an oxygen concentrator can monitor oxygen use and give you instructions on how to use it when you need it.
6. If you have diabetes, take your blood sugar as your doctor recommends and check the level regularly, especially in the early stages of diabetes. If you go onto a low glucose medication, you should review with your doctor all the other possible side effects.
7. If you have trouble catching up on your medications and are worried about side effects, talk to your doctor about other options.

    - If you are considered to be in the CVD group, then your doctor will usually recommend the current recommendations: a'very low LDL' target of less than 3.3 and a 'high' target of less than or equal to 5.5. The current guidelines for the European Community suggest that the current recommendation of 3.0 mmol/L (204 mg/dL) for UK population is in the CVD group. You may then get a higher goal of 2.1 and a lower of 1.2. You can choose to use a range of 'frequent use' and 'always' for your blood pressure. To check your blood pressure, simply take the 'blood pressure monitor' and the 'normal' blood pressure.
- - A person will be able to follow the recommendations, if they follow the NICE guideline closely (although it is easier to talk about someone without it).
- The guideline may be adjusted if the person follows additional advice from other health professionals, or the doctor is unable to make the recommendation on his or her own.
- If the guideline is used for more than one person, the guidelines may be further adjusted; example: one guideline may be adjusted for a person with heart palpitations 5-6 times a week, while another guideline may be adjusted for those with chronic heart failure.
- Each guideline has additional guidelines for certain areas. The NICE guidelines provide:
- The guidelines for adults are a general guideline relating to general health and health. They are not intended as specific prescriptions for treatment.
- The guidelines may be used to develop guidelines on further details. (e.g. for how to use the guidelines, in the section below about recommendations for medicines for cardiovascular and diabetes)
- Some guidelines focus on how to properly use certain parts of the medicine. They have been modified to be more specific to this purpose.
- These 7 types of guidelines may be used for different purposes. For example, a person with high cholesterol could use a guideline which suggests a lower limit rather than a specific cholesterol level.
- Some guidelines are used as a 'first step' in planning a patient management approach, but others are used as a'second step' or 'third step' as part of the clinical intervention or trial stage. An example is the guideline that uses a patient’s age as a risk factor for coronary heart disease in order to intervene to avoid it. To the contrary, a guideline which uses high blood pressure as the only risk factor for coronary heart disease in order to intervene to prevent it is called risk balance guideline.
- The guideline should be reviewed and adjusted on a regular basis to address the new or recently developed or improved information.
- You will need to update your cholesterol level before you take the next cholesterol level for the next year. This may have to be done at this time if you started taking medication.
- New guidelines are continually being published. The NICE guidelines for most of the non-CVD diseases in England are updated every three years. The guidelines for people with diabetes include a 'new' section that includes some new guidelines for people with diabetes in 2010. If you are interested, take the NICE guide to help you understand the new guidelines for diabetes (2010).

How do I decide when to start statin treatment for primary prevention in people with clinical CVD?

Expert Commentary

There are a number of factors which should be considered when deciding whether to offer a statin:

- The benefits of statins are greater in people with a higher risk of cardiovascular events and so the absolute benefit decreases at lower levels of risk
- The benefits appear to be slightly greater for primary prevention but the evidence is limited. (It should also be noted that in UK-based studies, there were no differences in benefits with or without atorvastatin 10mg, so the additional benefit of an increased-dose statin does not seem to apply to primary prevention)
- A range of benefits exists, including the treatment of hyperlipidaemia, the potential for prevention of coronary deaths and recurrent myocardial infarction (MI), and possible effects on stroke and peripheral arterial disease (PAD)
- However, the evidence concerning potential benefits specifically relating to stroke, MI and PAD for primary prevention remains uncertain
- When thinking about the risks associated with cholesterol-lowering therapy, it is important to consider that serious side-effects with statins are generally uncommon and most patients tolerate them well
- The risk of rhabdomyolysis is highest in patients who also take fibrates and especially when combined with statins (5% incidence in trials, 1% incidence in general population)
- The risk of developing diabetes is around 1%, which is lower with high-dose (40mg/day) simvastatin than with simvastatin (20mg/day), pravastatin (40mg/day) and atorvastatin (80mg/day). This risk may disappear after stopping statin treatment, especially in people who have not developed diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance at baseline
- The benefit-to-harm ratio is considered using the concept of number needed to treat (NNT) and a range of methods, including cost-effectiveness analysis. The NNT to prevent a fatal coronary event in people at higher risk is 46
- The potential to prevent a fatal coronary event outweighs the risks for an average statin-treating individual at higher risk (e.g. a 12 year life expectancy). However, it is also relevant to the clinician to consider the risk-to-benefit ratio when recommending treatments for individual patients, and there should be an open discussion between the healthcare provider and the patient on the subject
- A good starting point for treatment discussions could be the 2015 QOF/PHE Quality and Outcomes Framework (QOF) programme tool on shared decision-making
- For people with clinical CVD and who have already had an attack, statin therapy should be offered unless they have decided against it or the clinician has concerns about side-effects
- For people with a history of ischaemic attack but no clinical CVD, statin therapy could be discussed
- For people without a history of ischaemic attack or CVD but with multiple risk factors and who are high on the risk chart, statins may be considered, although treatment should be initiated with lifestyle support first
- The British Heart Foundation, NICE guideline for clinical care, and the European Society of Cardiology/European Atherosclerosis Society guidelines all give similar advice on these topics
- This statement is a consensus statement between NICE and the British Heart Foundation.

Questions for the discussion

- How do you decide when to start statin therapy for primary prevention?
- Do you use the NNT concept in decision-making?
- What role does cost-effectiveness play in your clinical decisions?
- Do you share the concept of number needed to treat with your patients?

i, the management of cardiovascular disease. BMJ. 2011 Jul 22;343:d5812. doi: 10.1136/bmj.d5812.

Cite this as: BMJ 2011;343:d5812.

Article contents:

- Background

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. Exercise interventions should be promoted regardless of baseline exercise volume, even though we cannot demonstrate clinically significant reductions in risk solely from moderate exercise (3-5 METs) (4).

- Aims

To establish a body of evidence, through systematic review, to inform effective practice for the physical activity (PA) screening and intervention in the management of CVD secondary prevention in both primary and secondary care.

- Systematic review methods

We undertook a secondary review of the literature (see Appendix).

- Results

Exercise had beneficial effects on CV risk factors [3 studies; risk ratio (R) 0.63, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.44 to 0.91]; quality of life, pain, cardiovascular function, depression and anxiety [9 studies; R 0.33 to 1.48, 95% CI 0.08 to 1.48], physical function or exercise capacity [5 studies; R 1.27, 95% CI 1.06 to 1.48], physical activity [25 studies; R 0.94, 95% CI 0.87 to 0.9], psychological function [7 studies; R 1.11, 95% CI 0.25 to 4.43], cognitive function [2 studies, n 25 R 0.66, 95% CI 0.04 to 3.40] and quality of life [3 studies; R 0.97, 95% CI 0.42 to 2.06]. These effects were statistically significant when adjusted for multiple comparisons, where exercise had protective effects (relative risk < 1).

The overall evidence supports a clinical approach to support PA for CVD secondary prevention. No evidence favoured either high intensity or duration in the treatment/intervention group.

- Conclusions

High intensity (10 METs) and short duration (min>30 min) PA can improve CV function and quality of life in secondary prevention. These effects are protective against cardiovascular risk factors but do not improve mental health, cognitive function or cardiovascular quality of life.

The review was commissioned by the Department of Health and Social Care (England), and supported by an unrestricted grant from BBSRC.

Systematic review registration:

NCT00836066, the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) CLAHRC North West Coast, Manchester: http://clinicalresearchregistry.nihr.ac.uk/trial/show/criteria=00836066.

We searched MEDLINE, Ovid MEDLINE in Process (formerly Embase), BIOSIS, PsycINFO, CINAHL and Web of Science (through 31 December 2010) for the following terms: cardiovascular disease*, exercise, physical activity, medical intervention*, intervention, or program*, or trial. We sought further studies until exhaustion, identifying a further 148 trials through searching of conference proceedings, journal websites and direct contact with trialists (see Appendix).

BACKGROUND 

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk is significantly increased in people with diabetes (Table 1). People having diabetes should therefore be followed according to guidelines for population risk management (Table 2). If this patient had diabetes, referral to a structured cardiovascular risk reduction programme should be considered. 

Figure 1 shows the CVD risk score, recommended strategies and associated risk reduction for CVD in people without a diagnosis of diabetes aged 40–75 years.

Figure 1 Risk profile for cardiovascular disease and recommendations (aged 40–75 years, not including diabetes)

Recommendation 
Based on the CVD risk score: 

CVD risk score < 10% ➔ routine monitoring of at least one target (blood pressure, lipids and glycaemic control). Review 6 to 12 months.

CVD risk score 10%–20% ➔ start to consider lifestyle modification; consider a statin.

CVD risk score 20%–25% ➔ consider lifestyle modification and optimise control of one to two targets (blood pressure, lipids and glycaemic control). Add one or two other targets if targets are suboptimal.

CVD risk score 25%–75% ➔ lifestyle modification and consider a statin. Further cardiovascular risk management considerations for target achievement are described below.

CVD risk score > 75% ➔ lifestyle modification, intensify interventions, e.g. maximise use of current prescribed medications (target aim and treatment should be reviewed as outlined below), offer specialist assessment and referral to a multidisciplinary team (MDT), cardiac rehabilitation, assessment for and management of comorbidities.

Figure 1 includes the CVD risk score table to be used in determining the CVD risk. The cut-off (95%) to estimate cardiovascular risk is based on a validated CVD risk prediction calculator (RRD calculator) available upon request. This score varies according to locality and should therefore only be used within its geographical area of reference.

Refer to 'Comorbidities' below for further details.

Risk Factors

Table 1 Comorbidities associated with cardiovascular risk

Conditions | Risk
--- | ---
Diabetes | 1.42-2.32
Hypertension | 1.56-2.76
Low HDL cholesterol | 1.40-2.66
Current smoking | 1.16-1.60
Family history of cardiovascular disease | 1.13

Based on Table 1, this patient is at a higher risk than someone with the same CVD risk score that does not have these comorbidities. In addition to the above risk factors, we should also consider factors that increase CVD risk, such as elevated uric acid and high levels of inflammation in the blood (CRP).

Cardiovascular Risk Management (Recommendations)

Lifestyle modifications

Recommended strategies for people without a CVD event (ie, people with CVD risk score < 20%):

Reducing weight if BMI > 25 (see 'Recommendations for cardiovascular risk management in adults' below for more details)

Daily physical activity of > 150 minutes per week

Document:
NICE guidelines on cardiovascular risk
These documents provide evidence-based recommendations on how to manage the risk of cardiovascular disease (including stroke) in those with and without diabetes. They also offer guidance on how to support people to stop smoking successfully.
Recommendations are divided into 6 categories:
- Blood pressure
- Lipids (cholesterol)
- Weight
- Nutrition
- Physical activity
- Smoking

Recommendations for reducing blood pressure
NICE has published advice on lifestyle measures to help people lower their blood pressure, to prevent a first or recurrent stroke (1,2). The advice recommends:
- people who already have high blood pressure to lower it (ideal BP within 5 years if it is very high or within 2 years if it is slightly raised),
- people who have high risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) within the next 10 years,
- people with stage 1 high blood pressure to monitor their blood pressure at home so they can tell their GP if it spikes and they can check their medication (the GP should prescribe a BP monitor if it is not available),
- if people have stage 2 high blood pressure, have another drug added (or increase one if already there),
- doctors should ensure patients are not taking drugs that increase blood pressure (for example, some anti-inflammatory drugs),
- patients with blood pressure higher than is ideal should be advised:
- to reduce salt,
- to increase physical activity,
- to try to lose weight (overweight reduces the efficiency of the kidneys in removing fluid from the body, which can raise blood pressure),
- to reduce stress (stress raises tension in blood vessels, which can lead to raised blood pressure),
- to reduce alcohol (4 g alcohol per day as a woman or 14 g per day as a man can raise blood pressure),
- to quit smoking (which can help blood vessels to relax and ease blood pressure).
Recommendations for lowering lipids
Lower than normal blood cholesterol (LDL):
- for people with type 2 diabetes who have additional risk factors identified, a statin.
- for people with type 2 diabetes under 40 who do not have additional risk factors identified, lifestyle measures only.
- for people without diabetes without additional risk factors identified, lifestyle measures only.
- for people without diabetes with additional risk factors (family history of premature CVD, coronary heart disease treated with medication under 55 years, angina under 65 years, previous stroke or family history of stroke under 60 years, or have a strong family history of premature CVD), a statin,
- for people with diabetes under 40 who are aged over 40 and with a coronary risk factor, a statin,
- for people with diabetes aged 40-75 with coronary heart disease not treated with medication, a statin, lipid-lowering drugs for reducing LDL, and a health professional trained in lipid counselling (5).
Reference
- NICE (2015), Clinical knowledge summaries: Cardiovascular disease: reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease (stroke),
- NICE (2014), CG176 - Risk factors reduction and stroke prevention

This is the main recommendation of NICE for my recommendation on diabetes patients:

There are currently no indications that diabetes is caused by excessive consumption of refined carbohydrates

Your diet must be consistent with the nutritional needs of all your patients

It should not be overweight, even to the point of high risk (at which there is no possible weight loss)

Avoid refined carbohydrate intakes that may include fruit, vegetables, nuts and leafy greens

Take the supplements you take to be 100% healthy (including vitamin E) (e.g. antihistamines)

Avoid foods containing refined carbohydrates which you may not be otherwise healthy for

Take additional support from other health care professionals because you need it

Follow-ups must be consistent with the current recommendations for Diabetes

Some people choose not to follow my recommendations, or choose to delay in eating until they can afford to lose weight, but those should be reconsidered. Here are some things I would suggest for diabetes patients:

1. If you continue to consume carbohydrates/cholesterol for food that may lead to problems, then the recommended foods are likely not healthy for you. Look for and evaluate the following foods:

• Vegetables

• High-fat foods (e.g. sweets, chips and beverages, pasta)

• Low-fat (starchy meats, poultry, fish, eggs and bread) (e.g. chicken, pork, ham, shrimp)

• Glucose

• Other vitamins and minerals

• Alcohol

2. If you continue consuming foods that are high in fatty acids (e.g. added sugar) and unhealthy for your health or taste for foods with lower levels of carbohydrates, then the recommended food is likely not healthy. Eating high-fiber foods can make you ill if you are not properly nourished. These foods include low-fat, low-sodium, high-sugar diets (with or without added sugar).

3. Foods that don't list or mention carbohydrates or high levels of a nutrient will still be good for you if they are in the diet recommendations included in the recommendations above

4. Certain foods will have certain characteristics that can harm your health or taste of or health effects of foods, especially those which contain carbohydrates and high levels of a nutrient such as fruit, vegetables and gluten.

5. Sugar, artificial sweeteners and salt could lead to significant health issues with your health and can pose a health risk to your children and your family. The amount of salt ingested can be affected by your weight and other personal factors and the potential for complications of anorexia nervosa, hyperinsulinemia or other mental health problems

6. Glucose (i.e. sugar) can cause some people to overeat or even not get enough. Conclusions in Health Care: the Global Framework to Health Policy
The Global Framework to Health Policy argues with recommendations from across the international community to address the challenges posed by CVD, heart disease, hypertension and diabetes. The Global Framework aims for a zero-rated single risk model for CVD in the world and offers a range of different methods for assessing this level of risk. The research on this specific topic will be in the next issue of Nature Medicine and should inform most of the discussions on the need to improve our understanding and prevention skills in health care.
The Global Framework focuses on the global health care system for prevention, diagnosis and care. It seeks to build in an internationally-supported and sustainable role in the health care system for all people. It further aims towards enhancing health as the key indicator of future benefit and to protect everyone, regardless of age, income, sex, marital status, education, marital status, geographical region or physical activity level.
A comprehensive index of causes of death for all 50 million persons across 35 developed countries in 1980.

The Global Framework describes the health problems of the people of the world and promotes a universal, comprehensive model.
The Global Framework for the Prevention of Disease states that current rates of CVD is at the rate of 60 per 100 000 cases in the developed countries of the world, more than double the world cancer rate.
At this level, rates of cardiovascular disease, cancer and high mortality are higher than those associated with other causes of death: chronic diseases such as heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke, cancer of the elderly, cardiovascular disease and cancer among women and people with chronic conditions.
Current CVD levels reflect the incidence of chronic disease in the underlying condition. 3. High Risk: 10-year risk of CVD > 20%
   - Implement intensive measures to reduce modifiable risk factors, like statin therapy to lower cholesterol, blood pressure management with drugs if necessary, lifestyle interventions such as a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and smoking cessation, and consider referral to secondary prevention programs.

    The CVD guidelines are based on a 10-year CVD risk assessment.
    The risk factors are age, sex, ethnicity, smoking status, diabetes, blood pressure, total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, and BMI.
    The risk of CVD can be calculated using the QRISK2 calculator.

    Parameters:
    age (int): Age of the person
    bmi (float): BMI of the person
    blood_pressure (tuple): Blood pressure in mmHg
    total_cholesterol (float): Total cholesterol in mmol/L
    hdl_cholesterol (float): HDL cholesterol in mmol/L
    smoking_status (str): Smoking status. Can be'smoker' or 'never smoked'
    diabetes (str): Diabetes status. Can be 'yes' or 'no'
    family_history_cvd (str): Family history of CVD. Can be 'yes' or 'no'
    ethnicity (str): Ethnicity of the person

    Returns:
    str: CVD risk assessment and recommendations based on NICE guidelines
    """

    # Calculate 10-year CVD risk using QRISK2 calculator
    # For simplicity, we will use a simplified version of the QRISK2 calculator
    # In a real-world scenario, you would use the actual QRISK2 calculator or a library that implements it
    if age >= 40 and ethnicity == 'White':
        risk_factor_1 = 1.04  # Age factor
    elif age >= 40 and ethnicity!= 'White':
        risk_factor_1 = 1.05  # Age factor for non-white ethnicity
    else:
        risk_factor_1 = 1  # Age factor for age less than 40

    if smoking_status =='smoker':
        risk_factor_2 = 1.4  # Smoking status factor
    else:
        risk_factor_2 = 1  # Smoking status factor for non-smokers

    if diabetes == 'yes':
        risk_factor_3 = 2  # Diabetes factor
    else:
        risk_factor_3 = 1  # Diabetes factor for non-diabetics

    if blood_pressure[0] >= 140 or blood_pressure[1] >= 90:
        risk_factor_4 = 1.4  # Blood pressure factor
    else:
        risk_factor_4 = 1  # Blood pressure factor for normal blood pressure

    if total_cholesterol >= 6:
        risk_factor_5 = 1.4  # Total cholesterol factor
    else:
        risk_factor_5 = 1  # Total cholesterol factor for normal total cholesterol

    if hdl_cholesterol <= 1:
        risk_factor_6 = 1.4  # HDL cholesterol factor
    else:
        risk_factor_6 = 1  # HDL cholesterol factor for normal HDL cholesterol

    if bmi >= 30:
        risk_factor_7 = 1.4  # BMI factor
    else:
        risk_factor_7 = 1  # BMI factor for normal BMI

    if family_history_cvd == 'yes':
        risk_factor_8 = 1.4  # Family history of CVD factor
    else:
        risk_factor_8 = 1  # Family history of CVD factor for no family history

    risk = risk_factor_1 * risk_factor_2 * risk_factor_3 * risk_factor_4 * risk_factor_5 * risk_factor_6 * risk_factor_7 * risk_factor_8

    # Based on the risk, provide recommendations
    if risk < 10:
        return 'Low risk. No specific recommendations.'
    elif risk < 20:
        return 'Moderate risk. Lifestyle modifications are recommended. This includes a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and maintaining a healthy weight.'
    else:
        return 'High risk. Lifestyle modifications are recommended. This includes a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and maintaining a healthy weight. |----------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Low Risk                     | Meets any **one** of the criteria listed in the above table.                         |

| High Risk                    | Meets **three or more** criteria or has hypertension and/or diabetes.            |
